wordpressPost.title: Employee Engagement News Roundup 10/30/2015
wordpressPost.content:
The WeSpire Employee Engagement Weekly News Roundup aggregates the top employee engagement articles from around the industry to keep you informed and inspire positive impact in your organization.

Why HR Belongs in the C-Suite

Chief Human Resources Officers (CHROs) are responsible for much more than talent management; they are strategic thinkers, employee advocates, supportive, and embody an organization’s values entirely. Through their thought leadership, innovative thinking and strategic initiatives they directly aid in an organization’s success. The author believes CHRO’s belong in the C-Suite especially to improve employee engagement: CHROs are instrumental in promoting engagement, which has the added benefit of profiling the company’s talent pool and as a result, making for a more sustainable enterprise.

Millennials’ Expectations Transform Employee Engagement: The New Corporate Philanthropy

As Millennials continue to flood the workplace, companies are competing to attract top talent, but their old strategies aren’t working. According to the author, purpose and passion have become Millennials’ top priority when seeking out work. A recent PwC survey found that 9 out of 10 employees gravitate towards companies who have corporate social responsibility (CSR) initiatives. The author shares her experience establishing Covestro’s Employee Engagement Institute (CEEI), at Robert Morris University. She explains that working with non-profits and welcoming skills based volunteerism can be a transformative strategy to attract and retain top talent.

Strong sustainability track record can account for 11% of a company’s value ‘ report

A company’s corporate reputation plays an integral role in their overall company value and employee engagement. A recent study by Project ROI claims that a top level corporate reputation for responsibility and sustainability can account for 11% of a firm’s value. In addition, responsible companies experience increased employee productivity and lower turnover rates. Interestingly, the study also found employees accept higher salaries from companies with poor reputations, while employees are willing to take a pay cut from organizations with a strong ones. While all organizations should strive to be responsible, the author explains only truly committed organizations stand out’and reap the benefits.

Is a higher salary the only way business can boost staff loyalty?

Employees now more than ever are seeking purposeful work from socially responsible employers. Volunteer programs have become influential in satisfying both of these criteria. The author shares examples of companies around the world who have effectively implemented volunteering opportunities into their company culture, such as GSK, Deutsche Bank, and Accenture. The results: higher employee engagement, increased retention rates, and deeper employee connection and appreciation for their organization. While offering skills based volunteering may not be possible for every organization, finding new ways to create purposeful work for your employees will be crucial in retaining top talent.

When It Comes to True Employee Engagement, No Pain Equals No Gain

The author explains that the painful moments you endure in creating your company culture are critical to creating true employee engagement. For most companies, these painful moments include criticism, asking important questions, and collecting data. He believes that organizations should focus on internalizing criticism the same way they do positive feedback, ask thought-provoking and meaningful questions, and find bright spots within their employee engagement data. Doing so will guarantee that they have all the answers and resources needed to create a truly enriching and authentic employee engagement program.
